So how did you feel when you first found out that Bethan had a learning disability?
Oh, God, I don't know. I've had to confuse her more than anything.
The thing was that Bethan was born and a lot of my friends are having kids at the same time.
So she looked healthy. She looked beautiful, you know, to look at.
But there were milestones that she wasn't compared to my friend's kids.
So she would be walking at the same time as them, not talking at the same time as them.

She was nowhere near that.

just the sense of that, you know, now we can get on with doing something about it.

we are the only constant in their lives from the time they come on board as adults when they're 18, 29, to the time they die.

How easy has it been for your members of the learning disability to get used to leading the organization and making decisions?
That's a hard one, really.
I mean, we had a self-applicacy group in Kennedy, Cuncone, Kennedy Dump People's Fellows, and that finished.
And we were left to know with no advocacy service, self-application, because there wasn't any advocacy service.
But legislation has changed, not for the better, I'm afraid.
So Mencak Kennedy decided that we'd set up our own self-advocacy group.
And it was called, the members called it our voice, our choice.
And we helped it for a while, facilitated it, helped them with meetings, administrations, stuff like that, until they were set up.
And we consciously then let them go.
Because one thing with self-advocacy, it has to be independent of any other organization, any other service, because otherwise it won't work.
And we were really, really big on that.
But it is difficult to get them to run the meeting effectively.
So you still need to support them.
But it has to be that it's supporting them and not doing it for them.
And that's been a really difficult transition, especially if you're somebody like me.
I like to be in control of stuff.
And I, you know, I blame myself a lot where I'd be in the meeting and I'd say, oh, you don't do it that way.
You do it this way, you know, and then I'm trying to have the hands off.
It's more my problem, I think, than their problem.
Because on Saturday they had a meeting and I would stick myself out of the chair and I'd be like, I'm not saying a word and keep your mouth.
And you know what? They ran it fine.
So I think there's a bit of confidence in letting them get on with it, but be there to be supportive and not be doing it.
So Mencap-Carradiguan is separate to Mencap-Cumbria.
What's that relationship been like in the last 20 years?
It's been an odd one, really, to be honest with you, because first of all, it's difficult for people outside that don't know us to differentiate the two.

Mencap-Cumbria is a charity and it's throughout Wales.
And we're not the same in as much. We have the same ideals.
We have the same hopes and so forth for our members.

Could you tell me a little bit about the Comic Con?

we've got gardening, artwork, Sunday lunch clubs, all sorts of things.

What was the impact of Covid on the organisation?
Crikey. That was a big shock to us because everything came to a stop. It wasn't a gradual stop. It was a stop.
So all our social clubs couldn't meet.
So we, within a week, decided, and we were probably one of the first, to use social media.
I found out about Zoom. Never heard of Zoom before. Still don't quite understand how it works, but anyway.
And very, very quickly, we were using FaceTime. We got a lot of volunteers along.
And we did things with our members. Things like Monday night was a quiz night.
Wednesday, Saturday, comedy nights. Everyone had to come along with a joke.
Marks had a ten. We had Friday coffee morning. Then we had things like Keep Fit.
We could have volunteers that did Keep Fit with them. We did some cooking. We didn't do much cooking actually. We could have done more.
We had Tom, Tom Evans, who is a writer. He's got a relative with learning disabilities.
And he wrote a whole book, if you like. And he read, he wrote it and read it every single day of the lockdowns.
Every day. And other people did, I mean, Rihanna, for instance, she used to do the competition of the week where she'd take a photo of a jar with jelly beans in it.
And you had to guess how many. So on a Monday, you'd have the picture and then people would be sending in their guessing, you know.
And the next week would be a box of pencils. How many pencils? Things like that.
They would get involved with that sort of thing. And then we got a pop group Dunlom was friends with.
And the lead singer did a Nightwake, sang all the songs from the group.
And we had George from Captain Entertainment having discos.
And we were really, we were fat, I used to say, and busy an hour with them when we were before Covid.
But the other thing that we did as well was we were on the other side of the phone.
If people were in need of any help, and we would refer, like if people couldn't get to a shop or something like that, we could ring the authorities and get them to a food bank or whatever.
So there was that link. But what we were conscious of was that not many people, people who weren't on social media, how were they coping?
We were disappointed, I have to say, with some of the supported housing organizations not being supportive and getting their members on social media.
Every house has got a computer stuck in their office. That's a problem.
But there was nobody, I can remember one support worker telling me, I don't agree with social media.
I think it's terrible that they can, you know, can all sort of problems. I don't really care what you think.
I want that person on Facebook. He's able to do it. I want you to support it. And as it was, you have to.
But I think the worst thing about Covid for certain people who weren't in contact with us through social media or Zoom was they missed their friends.
You know, a lot of people think people with disabilities, you know, they're not really good at communicating or socializing or, you know, they don't have eye contact.
So how can they make friends and have, you know, all of this business?
But actually, they are the most social people in the world and they really, really missed Gateway.
There was one person who used to ring me every week. I know what he said to me on the other side of the phone was,
When is the Christmas disc of? When is the Gateway? When is, when am I going to see my friends and stuff?
And they were breaking their hearts because they could, they just didn't have a social life.
And I always think, and I see these policies coming from the World Trade Assembly, you know, supporting people to go to work,
whether they like it or not, they're going to be supposed to go to work or supporting people to live independently, to cook, to pay their bills.
I know it's a different things, but there's very, very little.
I was hoping they'd learn from the Covid situation, fairly little about social life.
And they are allowed, they have a right to have a social life.
But there's very little provision out there for a social life, supporting people to go out, not just go to the pub.
I've seen support workers taking people for a coffee. Going for a coffee seems to be a big thing.
But the thing about socialising, helping them to get to know other people, for instance, that's what we aim to do with our gateways.
And we, you know, a social worker who sits next to a person in one of our gateways and they don't get involved with their client or other people.
They're there on their phones. We take a photo of them and we show them it.
So this is not the way to support people. So we encourage our social workers and support workers.
And they do to not only get involved with the clients, but also get involved with the whole group so the client can get to know people, be friendly, you know, socialise.
And they get a lot more out of their social events by doing that, really.
They missed it over coffee.
And then I think we're getting really upset.
But I tell you, the first gateway part of the plant, I mean, there were tears, you know, there were just hugs.
Although we weren't supposed to hug, we were.
But that was the first time we had was really emotional, which just goes to show that people with disabilities can, you know, have certain relationships that are really important to them.
When lockdown ended and things got back to normal, did things for Mencap Cairdegon get back to normal straight away or?
We really wanted to get back straight away into normality.
There were legislations that stopped us to do it as fast as we could do, I suppose.
You know, we had to have our meetings outside instead of inside and all of this business.
We had to have masks. We had to do this, we had that, which, you know, made life a little bit difficult.
But I would say within a month we were back to normal.
Were the members back to normal?
Yeah, to a certain degree, I think.
I think it took them a bit of time, you know, with wearing the masks and the worry of COVID and, oh, we can't touch or, you know, things like that.
And especially support workers who worked for agencies who were very strict about, you know, wearing the mask for a lot longer than they needed to or couldn't sit next to people.
Their regulations were quite strict, really.
Whereas we were more laid back, I suppose, more maverick, more in your face, which makes it more disappointing that a lot of agencies now, certainly the authorities, are still not back to normal.
The day centres are still not open.
And we're talking three years now.
The offices are still not manned.
You know, now if I want to get in contact with somebody in social services, I've got to go through the reception area.
They take my telephone number or my email address and then that person will come back to me.
And I know that person is working from home, which often means the baby's crying in the background or the dog is barking.
You know, my computer's down, my computer's next door, I can't, oh dear, dear, dear, dear, dear.
You know, things have not gone back to normal and it'll take a while, I think.
People have been given choices of working from home, which I think is good because, you know, environmentally it's good.
But they need to be making sure that the service doesn't change and the people that are working from home are actually working in a place that can be adapted into a working area.
And I don't think that's been done.
And I think we're missing out on services certainly because of that and the way services are run at the moment.
So they're far, far slower to get back to normal.
But as far as we're concerned, as if COVID never happened really.
